bestBHT.bht: But now I go to Jerusalem to minister to the saints, not to be ministered to, because he treats the whole action as already begun. The present participle indicates that the journey is part of the ministering. The Grecians, hearing of the needs of their brethren in Jerusalem, offered their own abundance to relieve their necessities. This act reflects the mutual regard that should exist among believers due to the unity of the body. The apostle excuses himself for not immediately going to Rome, as he was diligently committed to ministering to the saints in Jerusalem.

Henry Alford: 25.] See Acts xix. 21; xxiv. 17; 2 Cor. viii. 19. ministering, not to minister, because he treats the whole action as already begun.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 25-27. But now I go to Jerusalem to
Albert Barnes: But now I go ... - I am about to go now."
That he 'went' to Jerusalem according to his purpose is recorded in his defense before Felix Acts 24:17, 'Now after many years, I came to bring alms to my nation and offerings.'
To minister to the saints - To supply their necessities by bearing the contribution which the churches have made for them.
John Calvin: It was indeed a rare instance of kindness, that the Grecians, having heard that their brethren at Jerusalem were laboring under want, considered not the distance at which they were separated from them; but esteeming those sufficiently nigh, to whom they were united by the bond of faith, they relieved their necessities from their own abundance.

The word communication, which is here employed, ought to be noticed; for it well expresses the feeling, by which it behooves us to succor the wants of our brethren, even because there is to be a common and mutual regard on account of the unity of the body.
He excuses himself, that by a lawful occupation he was prevented from going immediately to Rome.
Philip Schaff: I am journeying unto Jerusalem (on the point of doing so) ministering unto the saints."
The present participle indicates that the journey is part of the ministering.
On this service, see 2 Corinthians 9:1-2; Acts 24:27.
Archibald T. Robertson: But now (νυν δε). Repeats the very words used in Romans 15:23.
I go (πορευομα). Futuristic present as in John 14:2.
Ministering unto the saints (διακονον τοις αγιοις). Present active participle of purpose like ευλογουντα in Acts 3:26.
John Gill: But now I go unto Jerusalem... to minister unto the saints... and though this might seem below his office as an apostle... yet the apostle's heart was so much in it, and he was so bent upon it, and so diligent to execute it.
...he postponed his journey to Spain and visit to Rome for the sake of it...
...and assigns this as a reason why he could not come at present.

bhtAttempts.bht: But now I go to Jerusalem to minister to the saints, not to be ministered to, because he treats the whole action as already begun. I am about to go on this service, as indicated by the present participle, which signifies that the journey is part of the ministering. It is noteworthy that the Grecians, upon hearing of the needs of their brethren in Jerusalem, did not consider the distance that separated them, but instead offered their own abundance to relieve their necessities. This act of kindness reflects the common and mutual regard that should exist among believers due to the unity of the body. The apostle excuses himself for not immediately going to Rome, as he was deterred by his commitment to ministering to the saints in Jerusalem, an occupation he was diligent and eager to execute.

This act reflects the mutual regard that should exist among believers due to the unity of the body.
